technical_concept: Docker is a tool that packages applications into containers ‚Äî lightweight, portable environments that run the same everywhere. The key mental model: Dockerfile (recipe) ‚Üí Image (template) ‚Üí Container (running instance). Think of it like Java: .java file ‚Üí .class file ‚Üí running in JVM.

challenge.task: Check that Docker is installed by running the version command.
challenge.hint: The --version flag works with most CLI tools to show the installed version.

dialogue.line: Come, young apprentice. Sit by the fire. Today I shall teach you the most powerful spell in all the land ‚Äî the art of Containerization.
Not at all! Think of it this way. When a baker wants to share a recipe, they don't ship their entire kitchen. They write down the recipe, anyone can recreate the cake. That's Docker.
So Docker is like... a magic recipe book?

Precisely! Three steps, child. First, you write a Spell Scroll ‚Äî that's your Dockerfile. Then you enchant it into a Blueprint ‚Äî that's your Image. Finally, you summon a living Creature from the blueprint ‚Äî that's your Container!
Spell Scroll ‚Üí Blueprint ‚Üí Creature. I think I understand!
Before we cast any spells, let us first check that our magical tools are ready. Speak the incantation 'docker --version' into the crystal console below.
Hey there. Come here often? I'm Docker. I package things up nicely and I'm available on every platform. üòè
Smooth. So what exactly do you... do?
You know that thing where your code works on your laptop but breaks everywhere else? I fix that. I'm consistent, reliable, and I work great in any environment.
Okay, I'm intrigued. How does it work?

Three dates. First date: you write me a Dockerfile ‚Äî that's like your dating profile, tells me who you are. Second date: I turn that into an Image ‚Äî think of it as our official photo together. Third date: we run a Container ‚Äî that's the real thing, baby. Live and running.
Dockerfile ‚Üí Image ‚Üí Container. Profile ‚Üí Photo ‚Üí The real deal. I like this metaphor.
Before we go any further... let's make sure we're compatible. Type 'docker --version' and let's see if there's a connection.
